name: 1979 Revolution: Black Friday
description: 1979 Revolution: Black Friday is a choice driven, narrative game that brings players into the brooding world of a nation on the verge of collapse. Play as Reza, an aspiring photojournalist, and make life and death decisions as you survive the gritty streets of Iran in the late 1970’s.
minimum_requirements: OS: Windows 7 SP1 Processor: 2.0 GHz Dual Core or Equivalent Memory: 2 GB RAM Graphics: ATI or NVidia card w/ 512 MB RAM DirectX: Version 9.0c Storage: 5 GB available space
recommended_requirements: OS: Windows 10 Processor: 2.4 GHz Dual Core or Equivalent Memory: 4 GB RAM Graphics: ATI or NVidia card w/ 1024 MB RAM DirectX: Version 9.0c Storage: 5 GB available space

reviews.review_text: Like most other Iranians, I get very excited about anything that has to do with us and our history, so when I heard about this game's existence I bought it right away. Now that I finished my first time playing it, as much as I hate to ruin the 69 reviews I thought I could share my thoughts:  I can't recall any other game that really focused on a historical event like this and not only told the story but also let the player become a part of it. You can make some choices that really help your character or the ones around him, or be their doom. That's already something that quite a few big game titles don't manage. But the story telling is flawed. Some characters have no personality or are so rarely there that there is really no reason to care for them, and there aren't many characters to begin with. I ended up only caring for two characters, and the second mostly just because his role just hit home for me. And just when things are really heating up, the game ends. And it's not even a big ending that really feels like one, it's more like listening to music and during the chorus your speakers just suddenly die. A lot of questions should have been answered, but aren't even mentioned again, and you simply don't get much deeper into what was happening which is a pity.  The gameplay was not that interesting for me aside from choosing what to say and occasionally how to act. What you can do most of all is looking for things and collecting them, which then give you a little insight on both what was happening during the revolution and also Iranian culture as it was back then and still is now, which is neat for those who don't know much about Iran but still perhaps too little for those who really know nothing. More important information can be collected by taking photos, and you do that in a very basic 'click at the right moment' minigame. Depending on how well the photo turns out, the more information you get. There's also everybody's favourite thing in gaming history: Quick time events! *sarcasm* Also, on two occasions I had to patch up people who were hurt and I have to say that that were just silly. Especially having to put bandages around the wounds, it looked really bad and out of place compared to the style in the rest of the game.  The game looks alright. It's rather obvious to tell which character models were worked on longer and which ones were rushed, and in just one scene, standing on one spot, I could count up to almost 10 copy-pasted NPCs. But I really did like the style they went with and enjoyed looking at the character I play. The environments were also done nicely, it really reminded me of walking down a street in Tehran.  I have the luck of rarely ever getting glitches and such in games, but there was this one point where I walked into a half circle of people in the hope that I could collect something in the middle, but then Babak closed the circle and I couldn't get out because he just wouldn't move. I had to restart the whole sequence and stay away from groups from then on which probably made me miss out on some things.  So, tl;dr: while this game is very flawed, it does go down an interesting path and I did enjoy my time playing it. It doesn't cost much, so I do recommend it as both a small 'collect stuff and achievements' game if you enjoy those and an alternative to a short and probably biased documentary.

I got this game because it seemed like a grittier, more realistic take on a Telltale-like adventure game. It's certainly more realistic, but that's simply because of the subject matter: it's historical, not using some comic book or sci-fi movie as its foundation. Indeed, the setting and the events of the time are the most interesting parts of the game. Sadly, that's not enough to make a game  good .  Just like an indie movie, the pacing struggles throughout. By far the best moments are when it picks up and you finally feel a sense of urgency. Unfortunately the same can not be said for a sense of agency. I got the impression that my choices would have very little effect on anything, and sure enough, they didn't.  The story focuses on a few different characters, but the length is so short and we know so little about them that it's hard to care aabout what happens. The culture and circumstances are also far enough away that they're difficult to relate to. And again, not having a lot of time to adjust makes it hard to immerse oneself in the world.  Every character felt like they were preaching about something - some viewpoint or moral or position. This added to a lack of emotion makes it a bit hard to stay invested and interested, as it sounds like you're just being lectured to for most of the game.  There are some neat collectibles; the photo mechanic to acquire them was fun and added to making the environments seem real. But the quick time events were annoying and not particularly well-exected. Some only flashed on the screen for a second or were hard to read while others used obscure icons with no text or explanation. Lastly, some of the collectibles were mutually exclusive with each other (for no good reason I could find) which meant having to restart a chapter to acquire them all. This was particularly frustrating because you can't skip dialogue or cutscenes and there's no sprint. In a word: slow.  The icing on the cake is an atrocious cliffhanger ending. Nothing is resolved, despite this supposedly being a full, standalone game.  This is a story worth telling, but a game might not have been the best medium for it. If you're heavily interested in the place and time then I'd probably still recommend it, but for everyone else I'd wait for an indie movie version. With a different ending it'd be worth the ticket price.

Very short(I finished it in 2 hours) but well worth the purchase as it was very well done, although the ending was rather abrupt and unexpected and didn't tie up any loose ends. I learnt quite a lot about the circumstances surrounding the Iranian revolution and the background behind the present day situation. It maintained a fairly objective stance about the revolution, even though it was told from the point of view of the revolutionaries. I also learnt quite a bit about Iranian culture and traditions. Very similar to Telltale games in structure and style, and also less buggy. I hope I see some more similar historical games from these devs as it was very enjoyable.

Great game, but a little expensive for its brevity. Superb use of language, history, and culture to create a very rich experience, I truly admire the developers for what they've done. I would say definitely pick it up, albeit during a sale.

A good and detailed short game! the story telling is good and the short time for making choices is great and make sense in matters like revolutions and the fast paced events that happen over and over. i guess i will play this game for second and third time just for figuring out what will happen in other endings. as i live in Iran, i can't tell you how much i liked this game. i wish the choices i made in this game would have happen in real life so the revolution of people stayed in people's hands not being stolen by 'Them'. Thanks goes to developers for this awesome historical adventure.

If you're looking for gameplay and length, this is not the game for you.  If you're looking for an exciting story that respectfully and accurately reflects the Iranian revolution of the late 70's, look no further.  The voice acting and dialog work well to immerse the player in the story, which itself is a careful balance between historically complex and emotional material. The characters' motives make sense in context of their experiences, and many decisions in the game that only lend themselves to bad consequences show how dire the situation really was.  It's clear that the game was made by an indie developer. Animations of extras are crude and 3d models are recycled, but this doesn't take away much from the experience and the game accomplishes everything it sets out to do very well. If you're interested in history or other cultures, you must pick this up. Hopefully, we'll see more games like this in the future.

This is a nice little game with a powerful story that is based on real event with fictive main characters. I can see that a lot of efford has been put into the gathering of information and research of the revolution. This game left me full of emotions and I am realy glad that games like this make it to the market. The movement of a main character is little bit clunky and be also wary that the game is relatively short, but that are my only cons. It was worth the money and I definatelly recomend this game!
interesting story but way 2 short and abrupt endingm it is replayable to see all the outcomes but dont know if it is worth the price tag though,  pick it up on sale not worth the full price

I was incredibly intrigued by the premise and I'm all for supporting indie developers but this is not a game. I never complain about games being too short but 1979 Revolution accomplished nothing. It requires you to make all your decisions uninformed and there's never really weight to those decisions. The story and the characters had 0% of development.  As a half-finished documentary is good. As a game is just not worth it.

From a historical stand point I think this game is very well done. I know that it didn't tell everything that happened during the Iranian Revolution and that it brushed over quite a bit, however for what it was it was quite well done.   My biggest complaint is that it just sends so abruptly. Right as the story begins to heat up it just. Ends. I seriously hope there's going to be more to this because I became quite invested in the story that was being told.
Good story. Moving and informational. Very Short though.

Very disappointed in length (took me 2 1/2hrs to finish) and game mechanics are awkward i.e trying to walk places. If I'd have known it was this short I wouldn't have purchased it. Storyline is interesting and the level of detail is engaging but this isn't enough to redeem it 1.5/5 stars.

Interesting interactive documentary. Short but that did not bother me - the ending did. I understand the creative choice but I expected more after the emotional investment.  I still recommend it for people interested in the revolution story, even though the game is pretty linear it is not directly clear how your choices affect the story, if at all.

Excellent and very promising to teach history ! I am personnally very intrested in this subject and i know this country, i am very satisfied in the balanced way they present what happenned. I really hope we will see more games like this.   Great work !
It's more of an interactive movie, and very short. Still I don't regret having bought it as it serves as a fun and informative history lesson.
About 100 minutes gameplay but perfect story about Iran 79' Revolution
Good game overall. Terrible controls!

Black Friday is a game set in an alternative universe in which the Iranian nation is plagued with bad optimization and low res citizens.  It's not horrible but there's almost zero gameplay, the dialogue is repetitive and everything just seems to lead to nothing. Speaking of dialogue, they're constantly awkward switches between Farsi, English and Arabic(Idk why)  I liked the Tell-Tale Walking Dead game even though I never saw the show. You would imagine a similar game based in my own country would be even better, and it could have been, but it wasn't.  ' Side Note ' They mentioned the political factions in Iran like, 5 seperate times, it's more of the clunky dialogue I mentioned earlier but it stands out.
The new update DELETED my current game, really?
Educational game but it kinda dissapointed me because of that quick ending.  Pick it up on a sale but not at full price.
Great game, looking forward to future episodes

This game is not very well made. Choices are mediocre to bad. Interactions are weak. I suggest people just watch the replay of the game on youtube for the story. The story is the strength of the game. You can watch it and laugh at how ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ us Iranian people are :)

This is a propaganda game. Do not fall for it.  The makers have obviously not seen Iran in at least a couple decades. Gaming wise, it is about 3/10. The story is fake, and has a lot of logical glitches and personal takes enforced in it.  I wouldn't be amazed if it was backed by a propaganda entity.

Even though the graphics of the surroundings are quite poor, it is a beautifully done game, the story of which soaks you not only into the events of 1979 iran but also introduces you to the fascinating iranian culture. I immediately fell in love and i'd like to learn more about Iran now. Thanks so much to the developers :)
Interesting story and it's educational. If you like Wolf Among Us, you'll enjoy this.

Bit of a mixed bag for me really   The games whole naritve is one i think more should exploit a historical plot where you are playing a indirect part, the controls are not spectacilar but okay, the story is cut far to short far to early when buying this i played it then though i must have bought an episode rather than the whole game as it ended far too soon, i hope they ethier turn it into a telltale esque game as it has some much potential still a couple of gliches like the if you listen to the car radio in one of the chapter you then cannot walk away and just stand there while it repeats! it very much reminds me of the same mentality of this war of mine and is all the better for it,   overall great idea, decent value, huge potential if they do decide to build on it, good voice acting throughout  Hope that helps

This is pretty much like playing one of Tell Tale games, only this one takes you back in history to the 70s, where you are a photographer that has come back to Iran during the revolution that eventually brought down the Shah regime, and turned Iran into the Islamic state we all know today.  The game opened on a really strong note, but I felt the tone slowed down, which might have been necessary to deliver more narrative, and allow for time to explore the streets and understand more about the revolution.   Game is very short, 2-3 hours. But the beauty of it is, the game designer didn't try to favor any side over the other, but rather let you live the historical conflict, and form your own difficult decisions.   One thing I truly loved about the game is the music. Enjoyed it all over.   My advise is to try this very unique kind of historic game, both as an experience, and support to encourage more future games like this.
